title: british airways lose engagement ring flight london las vegas
story: James Stannard stashed the heart-shaped diamond ring in fiancee-to-be Laura Dilworths check-in luggage to stop her stumbling across it.But he was left horrified when the case went missing after touching down in the city -  and was later found ransacked with no sign of the engagement ring.The heartbroken couple, of St Albans, Hertfordshire, complained but an independent claims ombudsman has since ruled the airline was not liable for the cost of the ring.Laura told The Sun Online: Im devastated weve had to go through something like this.It was meant to be a wonderful and life-changing experience, but instead it could have ruined our relationship.We both feel like were cursed now. James spent all his savings, time and effort getting this beautiful ring specially made for me for it to be taken so callously by someone who ransacked our case.James had been planning his proposal since the day he met Laura in September 2017.After finding the perfect ring, the 36-year-old was to get down on bended knee at a Britney Spears concert at Planet Hollywood on New Years Eve.But instead James was forced to come clean to Laura after she saw him get teary at the airport when he realised the ring had disappeared during the BA0275 flight from London Heathrow to Las Vegas on December 27 last year.Despite desperate pleas to airport staff, the couple was forced to accept the £10,000 diamond was gone forever.Now James must delay his proposal until he saves up for another ring.James said: I love Laura so much, shes my best friend and when you know, you know.So I panicked when the suitcase didnt come out on the carousel.I know I should have put it in the hand luggage, but I didnt want to risk her finding it as we went through security.Laura said: Im absolutely disgusted BA has done absolutely nothing to help us. Its insulting.Its obvious we are just a number and that people dont actually matter to BA.They could have just give us a couple of free flights for everything weve been through.James added: It was a once in a lifetime trip that will never be repeated.Im absolutely still going to propose to Laura still. Im just trying to think of a way to catch her off guard.A British Airways spokeperson said: “The independent claims ombudsman ruled that we were not liable for the cost of the ring, so we have provided all the paperwork to assist the couple with their travel insurance claim.As we explain on ba, we always advise customers to keep essential and valuable items in their hand luggage.

title: jeremy corbyn wants the bbc to reveal the social class of their staff but his top team are all posh
story: The Labour boss suggested today that it should declare information about the background of its staff to make it more transparent.But Mr Corbyn and his own own top team dont exactly set a great example for diversity and equality - many of them have attended top private schools, universities and had parents with influential jobs too.John McDonnellThe Shadow Chancellor, who has called for private schools to be abolished, went to the £12,000-a-year St Josephs College prep school in Ipswich in the 1960s.Dire-hard socialist Mr McDonnell even appeared in the private school’s prospectus as an alumni, alongside the caption, “Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer from 2015”.Seumas MilneThe Labour bosss director of communications went to the £38,000-a-year boarding school Winchester College, before going on to read Philosophy, Politics and Economics at Oxford.His late father was the former BBC director general, Alasdair Milne, and he left him part of his £3.9million estate when he died.He was also raised in a six-bed mansion in West Londons exclusive Holland Park, and sent his two kids to Tiffin, the selective boys and girls grammar school in Kingston.Barry GardinerThe shadow secretary of state for international trade was educated at the exclusive £30,000 a year boarding school Haileybury and Imperial Service College in Hertfordshire.He also went on to study Philosophy at Harvard, and did research for three years at the University of Cambridge.And his dad was the Olympic footballer John Gardiner - representing Britain at the 1936 games.Andrew MurrayOne of the Labour leaders closest allies also attended an independent, private boarding school.And the grandson of a Tory MP covered up his aristocratic background and dropped his double-barrelled surname to appear less well off.His father, Peter Drummond-Murray of Mastrick, was a banker and stockbroker from an ancient Scottish family who was a leading expert on heraldry.James SchneiderMr Corbyns head of strategic communications also went to the private Winchester College, after growing up in Primrose Hill in a North London house now worth £7million.He then went on to study at Trinity college, Oxford.His dad Brian was a financier, and his mum Tessa is a property consultant.Emily ThornberryThe shadow foreign secretary attended a secondary-modern school after failing her 11-plus, but chose to send her children to the selective Dame Alice Owens State School 14 miles away from her home and her Islington constituency.Ms Thornberry could actually call herself Lady Nugee, after her husband Sir Christopher Nugee, the High Court Judge, was knighted.She lives in a £3million house now in Bransbury - just a few doors down from where Tony and Cherie Blair used to live. The couple own other properties too.Baroness Shami ChakrabatiThe shadow attorney general and has said that she is against the reintroduction of grammar schools because they “segregate” young children.But it was revealed her 13-year-old son was admitted to the selective Dulwich College, which charges fees of £18,000 a year.Speaking to ITV she denied being a hypocrite, saying: “I live a charmed and privileged life, much more now than I ever did when I was a child, but people on the Left have often had charmed and privileged lives.“I live in a nice big house, and eat nice food, and my neighbours are homeless, and go to food banks.And not forgetting... Jeremy CorbynThe Labour boss grew up in leafy villages and large houses including the seven-bedroom Yew Tree Manor in Chetwynd - once part of an estate owned by the Duke of Sunderland.According to Rosa Prince, Mr Corbyns biographer, he enjoyed a thoroughly upper-middle-class, scruffy country upbringing.He attended Castle House Prep school and then a grammar - before going travelling around Jamaica and Latin America in a fashion similar to todays gap yearsI think there can only be one reason why he is doing this, which is to create an atmosphere of resentment and prejudice, to presumably suit his political purposes.Bob Seely MP described Mr Corbyns team as a bunch of posh Marxists.But there are others in his team who come from more down to earth backgrounds.Shadow Education Secretary Angela Rayner left school when she got pregnant, and went on to work as a care worker.Rebecca Long-Bailey, who grew up in Old Trafford, began her working life in a pawn shop, and also worked in call centres, a furniture factory and as a postwoman before she went on to become a solicitor. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: yorkshire scotts fish chip shop mandarin menu president xi visit
story: Scotts Fish and Chips welcomes busloads of Far-Eastern tourists visiting nearby York  every week.And owner Tony Webster, 56, who owns the restaurant, has cashed in on the interest by translating his menus into Cantonese and Mandarin.He also put his chippy on Chinese social media site Weibo to attract more Chinese visitors, chatting with around 170 Chinese tour operators to bring holidaymakers to his booming business.Tony said: Its growing, but typically we get around 100 Chinese visitors a week, which is maybe three or four coach parties.The word is spreading. The Chinese are very active word of mouth marketeers themselves, so by embracing their language and social media platforms, thats the thing that really seems to be working for us.The restaurant had already been popular with locals, but now the Chinese tourists have given it an international reputation.Most of the Chinese foodies visiting the restaurant buy its traditional cod and chips, but the shop has had to cater to some unexpected requests.More than £7.2 billion of British goods were exported to China in 2010 alone, and demand has been rising ever since.Among favourite buys are Land Rovers and Burberry clothes, as well as Scotch whisky.Burberry even launched a 21,500 sq-ft flagship store in Beijing to capitalise on their Chinese popularity.Tony said: They generally want hot water because they bring their own Chinese tea, and its generally tea leaves rather than tea bags.And then some of them actually want a pint of beer, so were fully licensed and have beers on draught.The best seller is a pint of Yorkshire bitter to go with their proper Yorkshire fish and chips - they absolutely love it.When Xi Jinping dined with David Cameron in 2015, he also tried Greene King IPA, causing a surge in demand for the beer in China.Scotts Fish and Chips opened in December 2012 and has won awards thanks to its rave reviews on TripAdvisor.Chef Manager Roxy Vasai was also nominated for Young Frier of the Year in 2016 which celebrates young talent in the fish and chip business.Tony puts the restaurants success down to its core values of great value and service.The tourists get a discounted rate of £9.00 for cod and chips.Tony said: Everybody gets a warm welcome when they walk in the door and the Chinese are always smiling.They want to eat their fish and chips, take their pictures, and then go on to the next attraction.

title: no deal brexit papers dominic raab
story: The cost of using your card in Europe will likely increase, according to a new set of documents on the No Deal scenario.The papers also revealed the Government plans to slap VAT on deliveries from Europe, increasing the price of most goods by 20 per cent.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab published the 25 documents in order to show that Britain can thrive even if we leave the EU without signing a deal with Brussels.They contain advice to firms and individuals on how to protect themselves from short-term disruption if No Deal does come to pass.The papers show:But there will be a knock-on effect if the EU doesnt guarantee the same arrangements for British banks, the paper says.It reads: The cost of card payments between the UK and EU will likely increase, and these cross-border payments will no longer be covered by the surcharging ban.That means companies will have the right to charge consumers extra fees for using credit cards - potentially leading to bigger bills for customers of firms like Ryanair and Airbnb.Another blow would come from the end of current arrangements which mean that low-value goods being delivered from Europe to Britain are exempt from VAT.The documents - dubbed technical notices by ministers - also show that even in a No Deal scenario, the Government will seek to strike a series of limited mini-deals to stop trade between Britain and Europe grinding to a half altogether.And firms were advised to employ a customs broker to help them do business in Europe and negotiate new border checks between Britain and the continent.Despite todays announcements, Mr Raab said he is confident that hell be able to strike a comprehensive deal with the EU over the next few months.And he mocked suggestions that the military would be deployed to secure Britains food supply - saying: You will still be able to enjoy a BLT after Brexit.Speaking in London, Mr Raab revealed that another 9,000 civil servants could be hired to make sure the UK is ready for all Brexit scenarios.He said: Our institutions will be ready for Brexit, deal or no deal.And he highlighted the potential advantages to Britain from No Deal - including scrapping the £40billion divorce payment we have agreed to pay Brussels.The No Deal documents cover sectors such as financial services, the nuclear industry and international charities.They reveal that British pensioners could be unable to claim payments without a deal on cross-border transfers between Britain and Europe.But ministers will avoid disruption to the NHS by unilaterally allowing drugs and medical devices to enter Britain from the EU without new checks.Earlier today, Mr Raab denied that No Deal would lead to widespread chaos.He told the BBCs Today programme: There are risks here, but lets not have the risks blown out of proportion, out of context,I dont think the word turmoil will appear in the technical notices.He added that there is already a stockpile of 200 vital medicines in case of border disruptions, and pledged to ensure there will be a six-week supply of the drugs.But Mr Raab also said the No Deal plans will probably never be needed because he is close to striking a deal with EU envoy Michel Barnier.He insisted: Im still confident a good deal is within our sights.We have got agreement on about 80 per cent of the issues.Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer claimed the release of todays technical notices was a sign of panic from ministers.He said: No Deal has never been a viable option. It has never been credible and I dont think the Prime Minister thinks it is a viable option.Dressing up the severe consequences as if that could be accepted or that could somehow be smoothed, is not to reassure anybody.

title: bird photograph of the year 2018
story: Peruvian photographer Pedro Jarque Krebs scooped £5,000 for wowing judges with his piece, Black Friday.Mr Krebs felt the title was appropriate because the flamingos reminded him of the fights on the renowned day of shopping.This group of American flamingos were captured mid-fight in a Madrid sanctuary.Competition organiser and judge Rob Read said: Bird Photographer of the Year 2018 attracted an impressive standard of photography and it and it was going to take a truly impressive image to win.Black Friday is an image which is nothing short of explosive it made an instant and lasting impression on a panel of judges who are determined to push the boundaries of perceived convention.Naturalist and TV presenter Chris Packham said: Here is evidence of our great love of birds.You can sense the ambition, see the dedication and feel the passion of the men, women and children who have striven to capture the unparalleled wonder of nature in these images.

title: corbyn proposes digital bbc to rival netflix and facebook funded by tech giants
story: And he said the BDC could work with other institutions a Labour government would set up such as a National Investment Bank and a Strategic Investment Board for increased public engagement and control."Imagine an expanded iPlayer giving universal access to licence fee payers for a product that could rival Netflix and Amazon," he said."It would probably sell pretty well overseas as well."     Mr Corbyn appeared to dismiss the BBC's large digital platform, saying it was "mainly a broadcaster" and the BDC would be "purely digital".The Labour leader slated the state of Britain's media, saying when it comes to news and current affairs "our media is failing".To open the media up and "make it more plural", he called for journalists to be able to elect their editors, saying  does this so there is "no reason" it could not happen everywhere.Mr Corbyn said, despite what people would think, he did admire journalists - his first job was on a local paper - and even called reporters who risk their lives for freedom "heroes of our time"."Not many people know this about me but the media is very close to my heart," he said."I think about them every single moment of the day - and sadly they think about me every single moment of the day as well."

title: gcse pass rates rise after major shake up of grading system
story: Alongside making exams tougher, the government has brought in a numerical grading system, with 9-1 replacing the grades of A*-G.After a trial last year, 23 exams were graded in this way in England, with all entries expected to be marked with numbers instead of letters by 2020.The sciences, popular foreign languages, history and geography have all moved over to the new system, following on from English and maths, which moved over last summer.Only 732 pupils in the whole country scored a clean sweep of top marks, consisting of all 9s.     More than two-thirds, 66.9% received a C, or a 4, or above, which is up from last year, and back to 2016 levels, which is the first year-on-year rise since 2015.The overall pass rate, anyone getting 1 or G or above, was 98.3%.This is down from last year's 98.4% and the lowest overall rate since 2007.Schools minister Nick Gibb told Sky News: "Over 80% of parents understand the new system. "We changed it because the new GCSEs is more demanding, there's more content to learn over the period of the GCSEs."Employers were complaining that old GCSEs were not educating people for the world of work and there was too big a gap between GCSEs and A levels."There is less coursework for pupils over the two years of GCSEs, instead with a larger focus on the end of year exams. Despite a progressive roll-out of the new system, pupils in England have admitted to being left somewhat confused by the new system, with some translating the new grades back into the old letters before they shared results with parents."Any change is difficult to comprehend, but the reality is settling in that they are in a 9-1 environment."For us, the biggest challenge is making that make sense in a business environment."A wider range of grades will mean a wider range of differentiation."The government has brought this in to help provide more differentiation at the top end of the spectrum." Sky News reporter Sarah Hajibagheri said: "Exams boards had billed the new 1-9 GCSE grading system as the 'biggest time of reform for a long time'."But under the new number scoring system, girls are still consistently outperforming boys across subjects - except in physics and maths."At the top end, 732 students got a clean sweep of 9 grades in 7 or more GCSEs. 4.9% of entries by girls got a 9 grade, compared to only 3.6% of entries by boys.     "Overall outcomes are stable with a slight increase of 0.5% of students achieving an A/7 (20.5%)."There was also a similar 0.5% increase in students achieving a C/4 grade (66.9%) - but overall results are in line with those from 2016."In terms of regions, Northern Ireland had the best pass rate at entries graded C and above, with 81.1% of pupils awarded the high marks.Wales' results were down though, with 61.6% of pupils this year picking up Cs or higher.London had the highest 4/C or above rate in England, at 70.3%.

title: what you need to know about the gcse grades system
story: :: What do the grades mean?The new grading system will score pupils from 1 to 9, with grade 9 being the highest mark and grade 1 the lowest.A pupil who scored a C previously would receive a 4 this year.What would have been a low A grade is now equivalent to a grade 7 and a high A would be a grade 8.The new system was specifically created to allow for more differentiation among high achieving pupils, as those students who previously got As or A*s will now be split between three grades 7, 8 and 9.:: What to do if you've missed your gradesIt is possible to retake some of your GCSE exams in the autumn to try and increase your mark.November resit exams are only available in mathematics and English language, and only for pupils who were 16 or over on the preceding 31 August. All other exams, including resits for other subjects, will only take place in the summer.If you have missed your grades, some A-level or college course may still accept you if you're planning to re-sit your exams.

story: MEDICINES AND HEALTH:: The UK will have its own processes and systems to manage human medicines and devices regulation:: Unnecessary complexity in medicine regulation will be avoided by title: expat brits who lived worked
story: NewsExpat Brits who have lived and worked abroad face losing access to pensions in No Deal BrexitLeaked documents reveal that pensions could be cut off if Britain crashes out of the single market next yearShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNeil Murphy04:32, 23 AUG 2018Updated08:30, 23 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailExpat Brits who who have lived and worked abroad face having their pensions cut off in the event of a No Deal Brexit, it will be announced today. Pensioners who have contributed to schemes in Europe now risk losing access to their pension funds if they are paid into a UK bank account, according to leaked documents obtained by the Sun. Current Brussels rules state that pensions from member state countries must be paid into EU accounts, meaning UK residents would be forced to open accounts on the continent to collect their allowance. Britain is expected to leave the UK in March 2019 as fears of a no deal Brexit grow in Westminster and abroad.  The UK will become a third country if it crashes out of the single market without a deal, severely curtailing access to pension benefits for OAPs. The stark admission shows Ministers are braced for lost access to pensions for UK expats in the EU.  The revelation is amongst 25 'technical notes' contingency plans published by Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab on Thursday - who says his department has a duty to plan for every eventuality. He added the plans are “a sensible, measured,and proportionate approach to minimising the impact of no deal on British firms, citizens, charities and public bodies.”

story: NewsJeremy Corbyn accuses private companies of profiting from the misery of asylum seekersHe spoke out after Serco announced a plan to change the locks on the homes of would be immigrations whose applications had been refusedShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics20:47, 22 AUG 2018NewsLabour leader Jeremy Corbyn at Possilpark parish church in Glasgow to meet with asylum seekers who are being threatened with eviction by Serco. The Labour leader spoke out after Serco announced a plan to change the locks on the homes of would be immigrations whose applications had been refused. After meeting families facing eviction in Glasgow, he said Labour would end the “ugly and discredited” system of privatisation. Hundreds of people could be locked out of their homes if Serco presses ahead with its plans to change the locks. The company says it has been left to “pick up the bills” for asylum seekers who have had their applications overturned and their Home Office funding stopped.  Mr Corbyn said the treatment of the refugees was “appalling.” “This is not how our country should treat people seeking help,” he said. He added: “It is time for the Tories to end the failed privatisation agenda that is putting the public in danger. “Time and again private profit is put ahead of the public interest. This has to end. Asylum seekers who have fled horrific conflict and violence, and have since made the UK their home, deserve our help and support, not persecution from profiteering private companies. “Private firms have no business profiting from the detention of refugees and asylum seekers and we will end the ugly and discredited system of private firms running immigration detention centres.

title: jeremy corbyns 7 most radical
story: NewsJeremy Corbyn's 7 most radical ideas to shake up the media as he brands 'fake news' a 'travesty'Labour's leader claimed "most of our citizens think our newspapers churn out fake news day in, day out" as he outlined his plansShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter10:37, 23 AUG 2018Updated11:15, 23 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn has unveiled a catalogue of radical ideas to shake up the British press as he claimed the lack of trust in media is a travesty. Labour's leader claimed most of our citizens think our newspapers churn out fake news day in, day out as he outlined his plans today in Edinburgh. Mr Corbyn - who very briefly worked as a reporter on the Market Drayton Advertiser 48 years ago - has regularly criticised the media but also praised public interest reporting and the Manchester Evening News. He suggested letting journalists elect their own editors and the public electing members of the BBC board to break the stranglehold of elite power and billionaire domination over large parts of our media. Amazon and Netflix could face paying a 'digital licence fee' and the Corporation could be forced to reveal the social class of its bosses, workers and contractors.  The owners and editors of most of our country’s newspapers have dragged down standards so far that their hard working journalists are simply not trusted by the public, he said. It’s a travesty. A free press is essential to our democracy, but much of our press isn’t very free at all. Mr Corbyn claimed our news media is failing due to an unhealthy herd instinct, and the unhealthy sway of a few corporations and billionaires shapes and skews the priorities and worldview of a powerful section of the media. He added: I want to see journalists and media workers set free to do their best work, not held back by bosses, billionaire owners, or the state. The suggestions are not yet Labour party policy - they are still in development. Here are seven of the most significant.  Mr Corbyn said: In the digital age, we should consider whether a digital licence fee could be a fairer and more effective way to fund the BBC.  A digital licence fee, supplementing the existing licence fee, collected from tech giants and Internet Service Providers, which extract huge wealth from our shared digital space, could allow a democratised and more plural BBC to compete far more effectively with the private multinational digital giants like Netflix, Amazon, Google and Facebook. 2. The licence fee could be cut for poorer households  Charging tech giants could also help reduce the cost of the licence fee for poorer households, Mr Corbyn said. TV licences are already free for people over 75 or discounted for people who are blind or in residential care. 3. Journalists could elect their own editors  We should also think about ways to empower journalists, audiences and readers and reduce the power of media bosses and owners in the private sector, he said. One of the more radical and interesting ideas I’ve heard, which limits the power of unaccountable media barons without state control, is to give journalists the power to elect editors and have seats on boards for workers and consumers when a title or programme gets particularly large and influential. If, for example, an outlet gets a certain audience share, then its journalists could be given the right to elect their editors, making them accountable to their staff - and their journalistic ethics - as well as to corporate bosses and shareholders. 4. BBC bosses, staff and even contractors could be forced to reveal their 'social class'  The BBC could lead the way by setting best practice with complete transparency on the makeup of its workforce by publishing equality data, including for social class, for all creators of BBC content, whether in-house or external, he said. 5. The public could elect BBC board members Mr Corbyn said: One proposal would simultaneously reduce government political influence on the BBC while empowering its workforce and the licence fee payers who fund it. That would see the election of some BBC Board members, for example of executive directors by staff and non-executive directors by licence fee payers. To help decentralise the BBC, national and regional boards could also be expanded, with elections by BBC staff and local licence fee payers. All boards should be representative of the country, with a minimum representation for women and minority groups. He claimed: These elections need not be difficult to run and could build on the BBC’s current experiments with digital sign-ins.  6. Freedom of information laws could be expanded The Tories have shown disdain for FOI, the Labour leader said. We have already said that we would expand the [2000 Freedom of Information] Act so it covers private sector providers of public services. But I think we should be more ambitious. Currently, ministers can veto FOI releases. On two occasions, this veto has been used to block information about the UK’s decision to pursue military action against Iraq. That can’t be right. We will look at ending the ministerial veto to prevent the Information Commissioner being overruled. 7. Local newspapers could become charities

title: most unpleasant no deal brexit
story: NewsNo Deal Brexit plans REVEALED: All the grimmest small print as Tories issue 25 crucial warningsTories have published 25 notes warning of the consequences of No Deal Brexit. We're wading through the small print - and it isn't happy reading for you or your familyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDan BloomPolitical reporter11:36, 23 AUG 2018Updated13:18, 23 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tory government has today published 25 notes warning of the consequences of a no deal Brexit. They've deliberately been played down so people won't be alarmed at the prospect of crashing out in March 2019. Sweat-drenched Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab even denied there would be a “sandwich famine”. Calming fears of the unlikely event like an air steward, he added: You will still be able to enjoy a BLT after Brexit, and there are no plans to deploy the army to maintain food supplies. But as reassuring as this must be to everyone, by no means is it all good news. Mr Raab sensationally admitted the government is poised to recruit 9,000 new civil servants to work on Brexit - on top of 7,000 already - and said: Real livelihoods are at stake here.  Mr Raab also announced plans to recruit 1,000 more Border Force staff, on top of current recruitment for 300 border staff that is already underway.  Buried in hundreds of pages of small print of his No Deal 'technical notices' - of which there will eventually be about 80 - are some proper nasties that would make life more difficult in the UK. Already the plans have prompted outrage. Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer said: A no-deal Brexit has never been viable and would represent a complete failure of the Government's negotiating strategy.  Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones added: The writing is on the wall. No-deal would be a catastrophic failure of the UK Government that would cause huge disruption and serious, long-lasting economic and social damage to all parts of the UK. TUC general secretary Frances O'Grady said the reports confirmed no-deal Brexit would be devastating for working people. Federation of Small Businesses (FSB) National Chairman Mike Cherry said: The dangers of a sudden and unplanned no-deal Brexit have today been laid bare. So what do the documents say? We're rounding up what we've found in the worst of the small print. 1. It will cost you more to use your credit card  The cost of using a credit card to buy goods or services from an EU company is likely to rise. That is because cross-border payments will no longer be covered by the EU's very recently introduced credit card surcharge ban. In 2015, British consumers were charged &pound166million. Remain-backing peer Lord Adonis, of the Best for Britain group, said: No one voted for this two years ago.  Companies based in the EU, such as Airbnb and Ryanair – both used by millions of people – would no longer be bound by rules limiting what they can charge UK customers who pay by plastic. Who even knew that card payments were going to be affected by Brexit. It's time for a people's vote. 2. It will cost more and take longer to buy anything from the EU  This one is somewhat obvious but the papers confirm it in all its horrifying detail. If there’s no deal, UK-based payment service providers such as PayPal would lose direct access to the EU’s central payments structure.  This mean customers “could face increased costs and slower processing times for EU transactions”, the papers say. Meanwhile, the papers sketch out a whole load of new hoops UK businesses would need to jump through before importing goods from the EU. They include registering for a UK Economic Operator Registration and Identification Number and submitting import declarations to HM Revenue and Customs. Businesses are being advised directly by the government to look into buying up warehouse space for goods awaiting customs approval.  A stockpile of six weeks' worth of 200 medicines already exists due to the threat of French lorry strikes. But now the government is asking pharmaceutical companies to ensure they have an additional six weeks supply of medicines in the UK - on top of their own normal stock levels. The warning comes in a letter to pharma firms today by the Health Secretary Matt Hancock. Brexit Secretary Mr Raab told the BBC: There are potential issues around the border in the worst case scenario. So it's right, too, we will be working with industry around stockpiling of medicines for a working assumption of six weeks. 4. UK farmers face NINE-MONTH wait for exports that could bankrupt them  UK farmers face a crippling nine-month wait for approval to export organic goods to the EU. That is because logos on packaging would need to change, with UK producers being forced to drop the EU's organic food logo.  Yet the farmers would not be allowed to apply for this change until 30 March 2019 - and there is a nine-month wait. We are exploring alternative approaches that should speed up this process, say the technical notes - but they don't explain what those approaches will be. Lib Dem MP Tim Farron, of the Best For Britain anti-Brexit group, said: A nine month wait for organic farmers to sell their produce into their biggest market would see farmers up and down the country wiped out. The Government’s disastrous mishandling of these negotiations looks almost certain to lead to British organic farmers being put out of business – nobody voted for that. NFU President Minette Batters said: Not only would this be hugely disruptive but it threatens livelihoods and businesses in the UK. 5. Expat Brits could lose access to their pensions  It doesn't look good for Brits living abroad who still have a bank account in the UK.  They may face restrictions on their ability to borrow money and in accessing certain insurance.  In particular, UK expats in the EU could lose access to their pension income and other financial services, the papers warn. Lending and deposit services, insurance and annuities - which people rely on for a regular pension income - could all be affected. The notes warn that UK citizens abroad may lose the ability to access existing lending and deposit services, insurance contracts (such as life insurance contracts and annuities) due to UK firms losing their rights to passport into the EEA.  If there's no deal, any parcel from the EU to the UK worth up to &pound135 would have VAT charged on top.  It could be charged to the overseas firm sending the parcel - which in turn would charge VAT on customers at the point of purchase. This means a hike of around &pound20 on mid-value parcels being sent into Britain in a No Deal Brexit. 7. EU workers will lose an important voice in the workplace  No new requests to set up European Works Councils will be accepted after a No Deal Brexit. These are bodies within a company that represent European employees and keep up communication between them and management about the progress of the business. Labour - who repeatedly claimed Brexit could be an excuse to water down workers' rights - slammed the plans. Shadow Business Secretary Rebecca Long-Bailey said: The Prime Minister has waxed lyrical about protecting workers’ hard-won rights after we leave the EU. However, as is typical with this Tory Government, it was nothing but meaningless empty rhetoric. By not allowing new European Works Councils to form, nor having a contingency plan to replace them, the Tories are leaving British workers at a disadvantage compared to their EU colleagues. Leaving workers out of the loop and out of negotiations with management about pay and their terms and conditions. 8. New medicines will face a major chunk of red tape  New medicines will need UK approval before they can be made available to patients in the event of a no-deal Brexit. The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA), which regulates drugs in the UK, will take on the functions of the EU if an agreement is not reached by March 29. Products will have to go through national assessment before they receive market authorisation to be sold in the UK. The notice states: After EU exit, to market a product in the UK, an initial market authorisation application will need to be submitted to the MHRA and will go through a national assessment. MHRA will take a streamlined approach to approving UK market authorisation applications that places no greater burden on industry and ensures that patients can access new and innovative medicines at the same time as EU patients. Most new medicines currently come to the market through a licensing route overseen by the European Medicines Agency (EMA). 9. Brits could face longer queues at Dover  We're still not sure on whether Kent's main motorways will be turned into a lorry park as some experts have warned. There is still no clarity on whether customs will be collected at the border delaying lorries coming into the UK.  But the note does admit that officials will need to minimise delays.  It says: HMRC will work closely with industry to ensure its interventions are conducted in a way which minimises delays and additional burdens for legitimate trade, while robustly ensuring compliance.  10. There'll be new horrifying pictures of lungs on cigarette packs  We know, we know - get your tiny violin for costs incurred to tobacco firms. But really, tobacco companies will have to come up with some new horrifying pictures of people’s lungs - because the “existing picture library is owned by the European Commission”. The Government says cigarette and tobacco packets will have to have the new pictures from day one of when we leave the EU. 11. Bad news for hunters?  The European Firearms Pass would no longer be available for people in the UK taking their personal firearms to the EU. They should still be allowed to take them as a temporary export.  However, they would need to be sure that the individual country will let them re-export them - i.e. bring them back to the EU. 12. Britain's men could have to do more masturbating. All for Britain, of course

title: tories held secret talks keep
story: NewsTories held talks to keep the lights on following “no-deal” BrexitDraft contingency plans include a mass import of generators to ensure sufficient capacityShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent22:00, 22 AUG 2018Updated12:59, 23 AUG 2018NewsBritain's Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union, Dominic Raab (Image: REUTERS)Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tories have held talks to keep the lights on following a “no-deal” Brexit. Draft contingency plans include a mass import of generators to ensure sufficient capacity. The news comes as the Government today publishes the first in a series of papers setting out consequences of no deal. They are thought to cover aviation safety, nuclear power, medicines, rights of Brits living in the EU, haulage and fishing. But the Tories are said to be hiding Belfast energy plans because they are so “incendiary”.  Business Secretary Greg Clark is believed to have discussed a deal to keep the lights on in Northern Ireland when he visited on 6 August. A UK government spokesperson said: “It is of course right that we prepare for any eventuality, including the unlikely event that we do not come to an agreement with the EU. “As outlined in the EU Exit White Paper, negotiators have already made good progress on a legal provision to underpin the Single Electricity Market in the Withdrawal Agreement and the UK will work with Ireland and the EU in an effort to ensure that the Single Electricity Market is maintained in any future scenario. Tanaiste Simon Coveney downplayed concerns. He tweeted: Stories about electricity in N Ireland post Brexit should be kept in context. The all-island energy market is one of the great North/South successes that all sides are determined to protect. Tomorrow Brexit Minister Dominic Raab is expected to play down announcements as part of the duty of “a responsible government, to plan for every eventuality”. He will urge the EU to be “responsible” and “pragmatic”. And he says the UK will take “unilateral action irrespective of EU reciprocation” to assure EU citizens in the UK that they will not be “turfed out”.

title: tory defence secretary wants put
story: NewsTory Defence Secretary 'wants to put guns on TRACTORS' as staff moan 'the man is out of his mind'Gavin Williamson has been the victim of extraordinary hostile briefing to usually supportive press - by what appear to be his own staff in the Ministry of DefenceShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter09:38, 23 AUG 2018Updated09:51, 23 AUG 2018NewsThe Tory Defence Secretary has been branded out of his mind by staff (file photo) (Image: Getty Images Europe)Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tory Defence Secretary has been branded out of his mind after allegedly calling for guns on tractors, missile systems disguised as Coca Cola trucks and his own medal.  Gavin Williamson has been the victim of extraordinary hostile briefing to usually supportive press - by what appear to be his own staff in the Ministry of Defence. The mutinous comments are a major blow to the ex-chief whip, who spent months after his Cabinet promotion courting the media and holding high-profile political rows. The 42-year-old former fireplace salesman was marked out as a leadership contender after he confessed to an affair and clashed with Chancellor Philip Hammond over defence funds. But today, furious sources told The Sun they were at their wits' end with Mr Williamon's crazy suggestions.  One moaned: The man is out of his mind. His behaviour is totally bizarre and no one knows what to do. According to the newspaper, Mr Williamson came out with the idea of putting really expensive guns on tractors at a summit on the equipment budget. Witnesses were described as open-mouthed and didn't know where to look. Mr Williamson has since denied making the comment, according to the newspaper. But during a meeting with Polish counterparts, he was also said to have suggested disguising a missile defence lorry as a Coca Cola truck. No one really knows why, a disgruntled staffer told the Sun.

title: british tourist stuck dubai after
story: NewsBritish tourist under house arrest in Dubai after racking up nearly £40k fines in £150k LamborghiniFarah Hashi, 25, had his passport confiscated by the rental firm after speeding in the supercarShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly16:54, 22 AUG 2018Updated10:50, 23 AUG 2018NewsFarah Hashi, 25, who clocked up £40,000 in fines as he drove through Dubai (Image: WALES NEWS SERVICE)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA British tourist who had his passport seized in Dubai after racking up &pound36,000 in speeding tickets driving a rented Lamborghini is now under house arrest. Farah Hashi, 25, has spent days in jail after courts opened a case against him for criminal damage. He had hired the &pound160,000 supercar earlier this month but set off every speed camera on a busy dual-carriageway. The car rental company seized Farah's passport and he had to fork out &pound26,000 to retrieve it.  But police arrested the Brit at the airport this week on suspicion of damaging the car, and he has spent days in a prison cell. Farah is now under house arrest in a hotel. His brother Adman Hashi, 50, said: Unbeknown to us, when they were returning the passport, they opened a case in the Dubai courts for vehicle damage and vehicle rental. Farah, unbeknown to him, was going to the airport after he got his passport, paid the ticket, and was told there was a case against him. His passport was taken and he was thrown into jail.  He was there for the first two days in the jail, now he's under house arrest in his hotel. Dubai courts do listen. I believe they have opened this case unlawfully.

title: dad caught 3d printed knuckle
story: NewsDad caught with 3D printed knuckle duster he claimed was for a 'tattoo design reference' avoids prisonAdrian Grey, 40, told police the weapon was a toy after officers saw him hide it in his coat pocketShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly19:33, 22 AUG 2018NewsAdrian Grey was caught with the homemade knuckle duster (Image: WALES NEWS SERVICE)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad who was caught with a knuckle duster made on a 3D printer has been spared jail. Adrian Grey, 40, claimed the weapon was a toy after police found him concealing it in his coat pocket. A court heard yesterday how the white knuckle duster could have caused serious harm if it wasn't seized by officers. The weapon was allegedly made by Grey's mate using a 3D printing machine, which is itself prohibited in the UK.  But Grey, from Brecon, mid Wales, was charged with having an offensive weapon. The tattoo artist was given a three-month prison sentence, suspended for 12 months, at Merthyr Crown Court after admitting the charge. He'll carry out 100 hours of unpaid work and to pay &pound250 in costs. The father-of-one also pleaded guilty to possession of a controlled drug after officers found a small quantity of cannabis on him on the same day.

title: filthy jd sports store with
story: NewsJD Sports store's 'filthy' conditions exposed in behind-the-scenes photos by whistleblower workerThe whistleblower claims the toilets strewn with rubbish and staff were forced to use a dirty old mop to wipe the floorShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBronwen Weatherby10:41, 23 AUG 2018Updated10:48, 23 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former JD Sports employee has revealed photos allegedly showing filthy and disgusting conditions inside staff toilets and break rooms. The whistleblower says he snapped the photos on his final day when the toilets were strewn with rubbish and the floors were covered in grime. He claims staff didn't have any hand wash to use after going to the toilet, and workers at the Cabot Circus shop in Bristol were forced to use a dirty old mop without cleaning products. The man accused the firm of disregarding the welfare and hygiene of its workers, telling Bristol Live that its one of the reasons he quit.  He claims he was immediately shocked at the poor state of the rooms when he joined the sports fashion store, and colleagues said he wouldn't want to go in the toilets because they are so gross. Having worked in a number of other shops in the city, including H&ampM and Primark, he said he had never seen that level of uncleanliness in the work place. The man, who asked to remain anonymous, said: I honestly couldn't believe my eyes when I walked into the staff rooms on my first day, it is unbelievable how filthy it is in there.  It really feels like they could not care less about the welfare and hygiene of their workers. I've never worked in a place like that before, it felt uncomfortable and disgusting. He said on his first day he was asked to clean the staff area which he explained involved picking up all the rubbish and taking out the bins.  The man, who worked at the shop for a month, added: We tried to mop but as you can see from the picture the mop is very dirty and we had no liquid to use. I know they ask staff to sweep up sometimes but if you want people to clean then you need to give them the stuff to do it with. “Same for the surfaces and the bathroom, there was no cleaning products. There wasn’t even hand wash in the toilets until someone higher up visited and went out and bought some.

title: gcse results reveal northsouth divide
story: NewsGCSE results reveal north/south divide in England meaning you'll get better results if you live in the southStudents in London and the south east gained more than 69% grade C/4 pass rates while those in the north east and Yorkshire received less than 65%Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByIan Jones11:55, 23 AUG 2018Updated12:00, 23 AUG 2018NewsIn England London produced the highest amount of students achieving grade A/7 and above at 25.2% and the north east saw the least with 16.7% (Image: PA)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis year's GCSE results have revealed a clear north/south divide. Overall students in the south came out on top - with London producing an impressive 70.3% passes at grade C/4 or above and the south east achieving 69.6%. And while pupils in the north and the Midlands still achieved well over 60% passes at grade C/4 or above, marks were lower overall with the West Midlands coming bottom with 63.1 percent. In England London produced the highest amount of students achieving grade A/7 and above at 25.2% and the north east saw the least with 16.7%.  However, the best results came from Northern Ireland where an incredible 81.1% of students achieved passes at grade C/4 or above and 29.4% achieved grade A/7 and above. The biggest rise was seen in the south east of England where 1.2 percent more students achieved C/4 and above than last year. The biggest drop was seen in Wales, where 1.2 percent fewer students achieved C/4 and above. It was only one of two regions (West Midlands went down by 0.4 percent) that saw a dip in their grades. title: inside queens two storey childhood
story: NewsInside the Queen's two-storey childhood den dubbed 'the most glamorous wendy house ever'The 'little house' was gifted to Princess Elizabeth and sister Margaret from the people of Wales in 1932Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmy ColesMark McConville11:48, 23 AUG 2018Updated12:47, 23 AUG 2018NewsThe Little House, the miniature cottage in the grounds of Windsors Royal Lodge (Image: BBC)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBefore she got the keys to Buckingham Palace, Queen Elizabeth II was the proud owner of another home - a wendy house fit for royalty. The 'little house', as it is known, is a scaled down, two-storey, white-washed thatched cottage gifted to Princess Elizabeth and her sister Margaret by the people of Wales in March 1932, to mark Elizabeth's sixth birthday. For the last eighty years the house, dubbed 'the most glamorous wendy house ever' by Princess Beatrice, has been a play den for subsequent royal generations. It measures 24 feet long and eight feet deep, according to the Daily Mail, and has five feet rooms. The front door opens onto a small hallway with a kitchen.  A staircase goes up to a bedroom and a bathroom, which, when it was first built had hot and cold running water, a heated towel rail and electricity. Inside it had all the furnishings you would expect in a real home, including a tiny radio, a little oak dresser, a miniature blue and gold china set and linen with the initial ‘E’ paintings on the walls, comfy armchairs, fireplaces and even a fully-laid table and chair set. A bookcase was filled with Beatrix Potter’s little books. Designed by architect Edmund Willmott as a link between the Welsh workers who lived in cottages and the Princesses. Stunning archive pictures from the 1930s show the then Princess Elizabeth and her sister Margaret posing outside the ‘little house’ which was moved to the grounds of the Royal Lodge of Windsor. In 2012 Princess Beatrice revealed she had lovingly oversaw the restoration the cottage over a course of a year.  She said: Granny was very clear that for all the fabric she wanted very little designs. It’s such a little house that she wanted little flowers and patterns’ she said. It’s beautiful. I’ve been lucky enough to play here and now Granny’s a great-granny, so now Savannah [Peter and Autumn Phillips’s daughter] can enjoy it too. Other incredible images show Elizabeth playing with a pram in the house, and out for a drive in London with her nurse while her mother received the house on a trip to Cardiff.

story: NewsMum who spent £10,000 on looking like real-life sex doll insists it 'doesn't stop her being good parent'Cindy Moore from Manchester says she loves dressing 'sexy and slutty' for her social media postsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNathalie Bonney11:31, 23 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who spent &pound10,000 on looking like a real-life sex doll had insisted it doesn't stop her being a good parent. Cindy Moore, 29, used to weigh 17 stone and wear a size 24, but after dropping nearly seven stone and six dress sizes, she started flaunting her new look in racy Instagram photos. Dressed in fishnet bodysuits, schoolgirl-style skirts and extra small bra tops, Cindy says she posts the pictures for herself rather than anyone else. The mum from Manchester said: “I think people just think you post these pictures because you want sex or you want a man but I post the pictures because I think - wow!  You look great. I just post it because it makes me feel good.  “When I put a certain outfit on I just feel powerful strong, sexy - and slutty! “The sex doll look is big lips and big boobs. I don’t know if it was the look I was aiming for at first – people just said I had that look.” In spite of her doll-like appearance, Cindy has only had one breast augmentation, but has regular lip fillers and maintains her hair extensions. She claims looks are in part due to her natural face and love of make-up. “My mum says I have a sexy face, so if your mum says that then, your mum doesn’t lie,” Cindy laughs. “The boob job was quite a bit and with make-up and all I’ve probably spent close to &pound10,000. “I would like to go a lot bigger, probably about 2000cc.” Before her double Ds, Cindy was an A cup and although her increased bust size improved her confidence, Cindy struggled with the weight she put on as a young mum to her nine-year-old daughter Lacey and son Max, seven, Cindy said: “Before I had my kids I was always extra small in clothes size and then after I had my kids I just gradually gained the weight. I had my daughter, I gained weight then I had my son and I gained weight. “And then at the time I was going out with a guy who was into bodybuilding so I was feeding him up all these meals with loads of carbs because he wanted to get really muscular and what happened in the process is he went to about nearly 17 stone in muscle and I was 17 stone in fat.”  At her heaviest, Cindy says she was “about size 24 to 26 and nearly 20 stone.” Vowing to get fit and be a more active mum, it wasn’t until Cindy split up with her ex that the pounds really started to drop off. She said: “Just to keep my mind off what was going on with us I thought: ‘I’m gonna focus on making myself as healthy as I can be and getting in good shape ‘so I just started working out all the time. “Now I’ve lost the weight it’s so nice I can wear what I want. It gives you that new lease of life and when my kids see me they run up to me and they are proud of me whereas before they used to put their head down.” Working out five times a week and well on her way to a six pack, not everyone, however, has reacted to Cindy’s weight loss positively. Cindy said: “When I am out and about in public I get a lot of people staring at me and a lot of people look at me - guys will whistle at me and look at me but nobody will talk to me. “When I was bigger lots of girls wanted to be my friend and as I started to lose the weight I went back to be just being on my own again.” The mum-of-two has also faced criticism for posting overtly sexualised photos on social media while bringing up two children under the age of ten.

title: new gcse grades explained parents
story: NewsNew GCSE grades explained for parents - how the new scale and system works and why it changedThe new grades bring in a numerical system - but 9 doesn't replace an A*, here's what grades 9-1 in GCSE meanShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJo-Anne RowneyAudience Growth EditorChris kitching08:00, 23 AUG 2018Updated08:36, 23 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe way GCSEs in England are scored is changing as the government introduced a new number grading scale last year - and more challenging content instead of the previous A*-G marks.  The new grades were phased in in 2017, starting with three subjects last summer, with most others expected to adopt the system by 2019. Once that happens all GCSEs taken in England will receive numerical grades, but teachers say the switch is causing unnecessary confusion and will ultimately increase pressure on pupils. Here is everything you need to know about the new GCSE grades and how they will impact your children. What is the new grading system?  Pupils are graded from 9-1 rather than A*-G, with 9 being the top grade and 1 the lowest. The new scoring system was first brought in for English language, English literature and Maths. That means students taking GCSEs will receive a mixture of number and letter grades when they receive their results.  Why were the grades changed? The new grades were introduced as part of a new curriculum that was introduced in 2014 in a bid to drive up standards. The government said new GCSE content will be more challenging and fewer grade 9s will be awarded than A*s. Courses are designed for two years of study and are no longer be divided into different modules. Students take all their exams in one period at the end of their course. The idea is to create more differentiation at the top end of the scale to allow sixth forms and universities - and employers - to understand what level the young person is at.  There are actually two pass marks now as schools will be judged by the proportion of pupils that achieve a standard pass and above a grade 4 as well as being held to account for the proportion of pupils that get a 'strong' pass - grade 5 or above.  Is a 9 the same as an A*? How do the new and old grading systems compare? No, not really. The new grading system is a grade 7 is equivalent to an A, while 9 is above an A*. A grade 4 is basically a C. The idea is very few will get a 9 as they will be rationed.  If you get 7s and 8s that's very good.  Grades 6, 5 and 4 are comparable to a B or C, while a 3 is similar to a D. Grades 2 and 1 are comparable to E, F or G. The new system has kept U for ungraded. What are the new grades?  The top is 9, lowest is U.  Do I have the grades needed for sixth form? This will depend on your sixth form. Speak to the admissions officer at your preferred sixth form to check you have the grades you need.  The same applies for vocational courses.   Why are the reforms being criticised? The NASUWT union said the reforms are creating huge uncertainty for schools and will heap more pressure on pupils. It also fears the new scale will close some educational opportunities for students. The union says there is confusion over grade boundaries.

story: NewsPaul O' Grady leads stars and animal charities all with the same message about the ban on puppy farms: 'Thank you''The campaign for Lucy's Law has been smashing, it's great what's happened' - Paul O'GradyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAndrew Penman18:16, 22 AUG 2018Updated09:50, 23 AUG 2018NewsGet daily Celebrity Big Brother updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDelighted animal lovers were yesterday singing the praises of the amazing Lucy's Law campaign to end the cruel puppy farming trade. Victory came on Tuesday when Environment Minister Michael Gove vowed to ban the sale of puppies and kittens by pet shops and other dealers supplied by commercial puppy farms.  This will mean that anyone wanting a pet will have to go to rescue centres or deal directly with the breeders, so they'll be able to see the conditions in which the dogs are kept.  “I'm over the moon,” said Paul O'Grady, presenter of the long-running hit show For The Love Of Dogs featuring Battersea Cats &amp Dogs Home. “The campaign has been smashing, it's great what's happened, all power to you.”  Paul's work filming dogs at Battersea means that he routinely sees first hand the grisly evidence of puppy farming. “I'm not hardened to it, each case sickens me,” said Paul, the proud owner of five dogs. “You can always tell a female dog that's been overbred, the teats are on the floor, the vets can tell when they've had too many litters. “I'm constantly saying it on the show, never buy a dog over the internet, go to a rescue centre or a reputable breeder and ask to see the mother, and the puppy should never leave the mother until it's the right age. “You get internet sellers selling puppies that have not even been weaned. They will die, they will have all sorts of diseases.” Dragon's Den star Deborah Meaden called the government backing of Lucy's Law “fantastic news, adding: Thanks to a committed band of supporters”. Another Dragon, Jenny Campbell, tweeted “Awesome result”.  Ricky Gervais posted: “Unethical puppy and kitten farms 'to be banned' in England!”, while Broadcaster Kirsty Gallacher wrote: “What a victory, what a day!”  The message from model Jodie Marsh of Celebrity Big Brother to the army of Lucy's Law supporters was: “You are wonderful human beings!!!!!!!! What an achievement.”  MPs from across the political spectrum were full of praise.  Conservative Andrea Jenkyns, who spoke-up for Lucy's Law in Parliament, tweeted “fantastic news”. Labour's Chris Evans posted: “We need to make sure the legislation has teeth now so it’s a real deterrent against this cruel practice.”  Caroline Lucas of the Greens said: “This is great news! Government has finally listened to campaigners who have long been calling for a ban on third party puppy sales.” Numerous charities told of their delight on social media, such as Animal Advocate which wrote: “Can't thank everyone enough for making my &amp their dream come true.” Rescue charity The Animal Team posted: “Thank you for all that you have done to stop the misery of puppy farms, together we are making a difference”. The K-9 Angels called it a “Truly a great day for animal welfare”, adding “Thanks to all Lucy's Law supporters”. From the National Animal Welfare Trust there was the message: “Today is a great day for animal welfare and the NAWT is thrilled that the government has announced that they are committed to implementing #LucysLaw to ban third party sales of puppies and kittens.” Will Travers of the Born Free Foundation wrote: Animal champions every one of you - and a brighter day dawns for puppies and kittens. News of the victory went global, thrilling dog lovers campaigning against puppy farming in their own countries. The group Finding Shelter in the USA said: “Congratulations to our dear friends in the UK who never gave up on the dogs. Inspirational. We can do this too, Pennsylvania!”

title: school sees 10 percent leap
story: NewsSchool's GCSE results increase 10% after headteacher bans pupils from TALKING in corridors and playgroundThe Albany School's head Val Masson dismissed claims the policy is "old-fashioned" and plans to introduce even stricter rules in the futureShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBerny Torre10:46, 23 AUG 2018Updated10:57, 23 AUG 2018NewsThe Albany School in Hornchurch, Essex has seen this year's GCSE results shoot up by an impressive 10 percent in just a year (Image: (c) Mark Soanes 2018 msoanesima)Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA headteacher has claimed her school's impressive GCSE results rise is down to a strict rule of silence in corridors. The Albany School in Hornchurch, Essex has seen this year's GCSE results shoot up by an impressive 10 percent in just a year. Headteacher Val Masson, who introduced the behaviour policy to improve grades, has dismissed claims the policy is old-fashioned and plans to introduce even stricter rules in the future. Under the scheme pupils are banned from talking to each other walking between lessons and three times a day in the playground when lining-up before classes.  Ms Masson said the new rules have transformed the classrooms and led to a spike in results, particular in core subjects such as English and Science. She now plans to bring in stricter behaviour policies by introducing four weekly compulsory silent revision sessions. She said: “These fantastic results showcase the impact this new behaviour policy has already started to have on our students in a very short space of time. “We have some way to go but with our new compulsory silent revision sessions for Year 11s being introduced next year, we expect results to get even better.  “These teaching methods have been called old fashioned but I would describe it as pure common sense. “Students deserve the right to learn in a calm, quiet and academic atmosphere. Education is crucially important to the life chances of young people. We have to get it right for them. “These results show that we are on the right track and are giving students the chance to fulfil their potential.” Ms Masson, who took up her role in April 2017, said results for Ebacc subjects - core subjects including English, Maths and Science - went up by 10 per cent thanks to the academic atmosphere created by the rules. She added Progress 8 scores - a Government measure of a pupil's progress between the start of secondary school until GCSE results - had also improved.
